title: 106_hr5182
content:
The Act is titled the "Day Laborer Fairness and Protection Act" and includes definitions for various terms. The "Day Laborer Fairness and Protection Act" defines key terms such as day laborer, day labor, and day labor service agency. A day laborer is an individual who contracts with a day labor service agency for occasional or irregular employment, with wage payments made by the agency or third party employer. Day labor does not include professional or clerical work. The "Day Laborer Fairness and Protection Act" defines key terms such as day labor service agency, Department, Secretary, and third party employer. A day labor service agency employs day laborers for third party employers under contract. SEC. 3. EQUAL WAGES. Equal Rate: A day labor service agency must notify third party employers of the wage rate to be paid, which should be equal to the rate paid to their permanent employees for similar work. Day laborers must be paid at least the stated wage rate for all work performed. Employers cannot reduce an employee's wage rate to comply with this requirement. (c) Agency Processing Delay: If a day labor service agency takes more than 30 minutes to process a day laborer's work assignment, they must pay the day laborer for the additional waiting time at a rate not less than the Fair Labor Standards Act or State minimum wage. Transit time to and from the work site or agency is not included in processing time.

(d) Unpaid Wages: Any amounts owed to an employee that have been withheld in violation of the Act are considered unpaid minimum wages or overtime compensation for enforcement purposes. Any employer who violates subsection (a) shall be liable to affected employees for damages equal to the amount of denied wages, plus interest. A criminal provision applies to employers or agents who willfully refuse to pay owed wages with the intent to defraud. Any employer who fails to pay wages due to an employee within 15 days of the order shall be fined 10 percent per day to the employee. A day labor service agency must provide a detailed deduction statement to each day laborer at the time of wage payment. Each day of violation of wage payment constitutes a separate offense. A day labor service agency must provide an itemized statement of deductions from wages and an annual earnings summary to each worker by February 1. They should also offer payment schedules and hold daily wages upon request for weekly or semi-monthly payments. A day labor service agency must inform workers of their right to request weekly or semi-monthly checks. They cannot charge fees for cashing checks or for overpayment to the workers. SEC. 4. RIGHTS OF DAY LABORERS. Rights of Day Laborers include protection against discrimination or discharge for reasons such as complaints about unpaid wages, initiating legal proceedings, or testifying in investigations. Employers who violate these rights may face fines. Additionally, day labor service agencies must provide adequate seating in public areas for employment and wage notices. The Act requires day labor service agencies to provide public access areas with restrooms and water. It prohibits agencies from restricting day laborers from accepting permanent positions with third-party employers or from offering employment to day laborers. Agencies can still receive placement fees from third-party employers for temporary work contracts. SEC. 5. INJURIES. Employers must pay for health care costs if a day laborer is injured while working. Transportation liability falls on day labor service agencies or third-party employers. SEC. 6. NOTIFICATION REQUIREMENTS. A day labor service agency must post a list of employers seeking day laborers in the public area, including employer details, job type, wages, transportation availability, and work description for each job opportunity. The day labor service agency must provide details such as special attire requirements, charges for equipment, work site address and contact number, work start and end times, overtime pay rate, meal provision, and cost in the job notices. The day labor service agency must provide job notices with details like special attire requirements, equipment charges, work site address, contact number, work hours, overtime pay rate, meal provision, and cost in English and other commonly used languages in the area. SEC. 7. EQUITABLE EXPENSES. (a) Meals for day laborers should not cost more than the actual expense and cannot be a condition of employment. (b) Transportation costs for day laborers should not exceed 3% of their daily wages. (c) Day laborers must be provided with necessary safety equipment and clothing for work. The day labor service agency or third party employer may charge the day laborer for any items required for work if not returned. The day laborer should not be charged more than the actual market value for any items provided for purchase. Agency registration for day labor service agencies is required with the Secretary and State departments of labor, with a registration fee of up to $250. Department requirements and responsibilities are also outlined. The Secretary will implement rules and regulations for this Act, including penalties for violations. A notice with a toll-free number for complaints will be posted in day labor agencies. Fines of $1,000 for the first offense and $5,000 for the second offense may be imposed on agencies. The Secretary can suspend or revoke registration for violations or public health concerns. The Secretary will investigate complaints of violations promptly under this Act to ensure public health and safety. SEC. 10. PREVENTION OF DISCRIMINATION DURING LABOR DISPUTES. Section 8(a) of the National Labor Relations Act is amended to prohibit offering permanent replacement status or employment preference during a labor dispute over existing employees who engage in concerted activities. The National Labor Relations Act is amended to protect employees engaging in collective bargaining or mutual aid during a labor dispute.
